years.info: Black September, also known as the Jordanian Civil War was a conflict fought in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan between the Jordanian Armed Forces
years.name: Black September in Jordan

years.info: The Reggio revolt occurred in Reggio Calabria, Italy, from July 1970 to February 1971. The cause of the protests was a government decision to make Catanzaro, not Reggio, regional capital of Calabria.
years.name: Reggio revolt

years.info: The Corrective Movement, also referred to as the Corrective Revolution or 1970 coup, was a political movement in Syria, initiated by a coup d'état, led by General Hafez al-Assad on 13 November 1970.
years.name: Corrective Movement (Syria)

years.info: The Mexican Dirty War refers to the Mexican theater of the Cold War, an internal conflict in the 1960s and 1970s between the Mexican PRI-ruled government
years.name: Dirty War (Mexico)

years.info: The 1971 Ugandan coup d'état was a military coup d'état executed by the Ugandan military, led by general Idi Amin, against the government of President Milton Obote on January 25, 1971. The seizure of power took place while Obote was abroad attending the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Singapore
years.name: 1971 Ugandan coup d'état

years.info: The Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 was a military confrontation between India's Mitro bahini forces and Pakistan that occurred during the liberation war in East Pakistan from 3 December 1971 to the fall of Dacca (Dhaka) on 16 December 1971
years.name: Bangladesh Liberation War & Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts

years.info: The 1971 Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna insurrection was the first, of two, unsuccessful armed revolts conducted by the communist Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna against the Government of Sri Lanka under Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike. The revolt began on 5 April 1971 and lasted till June 1971.
years.name: 1971 Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna Insurrection
Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 & Bangladesh Liberation War and the Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts

years.info: The seizure of Abu Musa and the Greater and Lesser Tunbs by Imperial Iranian Navy forces took place on 30 November 1971, after the withdrawal of British forces from the islands of Abu Musa and the Greater Tunb and Lesser Tunb, located in the Strait of Hormuz.
years.name: Abu Musa and the Greater and Lesser Tunbs conflict

years.info: The President of Tanzania, Julius Nyerere, had close ties with Obote and supported his attempt to launch a rebellion in Uganda in 1972
years.name: 1972 invasion of Uganda

years.info: In 1972, Jatiyo Samajtantrik Dal was formed when it split from Bangladesh Chhatra League, the student wing of the Bangladesh Awami League, under the leadership of Serajul Alam Khan, M. A. Jalil, ASM Abdur Rab and Shahjahan Siraj
years.name: 1972–1975 Bangladesh insurgency

years.info: Following the deterring effect of Operation Vantage, Kuwait gained its recognition by Iraq in 1963. Both countries had ongoing border disputes throughout most of the 1960s, although often resolved and restrained within the history of Arab solidarity.
years.name: 1973 Samita border skirmish

years.info: The Yom Kippur War, Ramadan War, or October War, also known as the 1973 Arab–Israeli War, was fought from October 6 to 25, 1973, by a coalition of Arab states led by Egypt and Syria against Israel
years.name: Yom Kippur War

years.info: The 1973 Chilean coup d'état was a military coup in Chile that deposed the Popular Unity government of President Salvador Allende
years.name: 1973 Chilean coup d'etat

years.info: Following the 1973 Chilean coup d'état, an armed leftist resistance movement against Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship developed until 1990 when democracy was restored. ... After the return to democracy was initiated in 1990 the bulk of the armed groups demobilized.
years.name: Armed resistance in Chile (1973–90)

years.info: The Oromo conflict is an ongoing and longstanding conflict between the Oromo people and the Ethiopian government. The OLF formed to fight the Ethiopian Empire to liberate the Oromo people and establish an independent Oromia state
years.name: Oromo Conflict

years.info: The Turkish invasion of Cyprus, code-named by Turkey as Operation Atilla, was launched on 20 July 1974, following the Cypriot coup d'état on 15 July 1974
years.name: Turkish invasion of Cyprus

years.info: The Arube uprising, also known as Arube mutiny and Arube Coup, was a military coup d'état attempt organized on 23–24 March 1974 by discontented elements of the Uganda Army to overthrow Ugandan President Idi Amin.
years.name: Arube uprising

years.info: The Battle of the Paracel Islands was a military engagement between the naval forces of China and South Vietnam in the Paracel Islands on January 19, 1974. The battle was an attempt by the South Vietnamese navy to expel the Chinese navy from the vicinity.
years.name: Battle of the Paracel Islands

years.info: The Ethiopian Civil War was a civil war in Ethiopia and present day Eritrea, fought between the Ethiopian military junta communist governments and Ethio-Eritrean anti-government rebels from September 1974 to June 1991.
years.name: Ethiopian Civil War

years.info: The Second Iraqi–Kurdish War was the second chapter of the Barzani rebellion, initiated by the collapse of the Kurdish autonomy talks and the consequent Iraqi offensive against rebel KDP troops of Mustafa Barzani during 1974–1975
years.name: Second Iraqi–Kurdish War

years.info: Iranian victory 1975 Algiers Agreement Iran consolidates control over the Shatt al-Arab/Arvand Rud waterway Tensions between Iran and Iraq over the disputed waterway and border escalate into a full-scale war in 1980
years.name: 1974–75 Shatt al-Arab clashes

years.info: In July 1975, the Muslim Youth, with help from the Pakistani intelligence, staged an uprising against the government in Massoud's Panjshir Valley. The group, which included Massoud, hoped to gain civilian support, but the plan backfired when the locals instead chased them to the mountains.
years.name: Islamist uprising in the Panjshir Valley

years.info: Two soldiers and an officer of the Indian Army were killed in a “violent face-off” in Galwan Valley on Tuesday, 16 June. Casualties have been reported on the Chinese side as well.
years.name: 1975 China-India border skirmish

years.info: The Third Indochina War, commonly known as the Cambodian–Vietnamese War, started on 1 May 1975 when the Kampuchean Revolutionary Army invaded the Vietnamese island of Phu Quoc.
years.name: Third Indochina War & Part of Indochina Wars

years.info: The Angolan Civil War was a civil war in Angola, beginning in 1975 and continuing, with interludes, until 2002. The war began immediately after Angola became independent from Portugal in November 1975
years.name: Angolan Civil War

years.info: The Cabinda War is an ongoing separatist insurgency, waged by the Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda against the government of Angola. FLEC aims at the restoration of the self-proclaimed Republic of Cabinda, located within the borders of the Cabinda province of Angola
years.name: Cabinda War

years.info: The Western Sahara conflict is an ongoing conflict between the Polisario Front and the Kingdom of Morocco
years.name: Western Sahara War & Part of the Western Sahara conflict

years.info: The PUK insurgency was a low-level rebellion of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan against Baathist Iraq from 1975-1979, following the defeat of the Kurdistan Democratic Party in the Second Iraqi–Kurdish War
years.name: PUK insurgency

years.info: The Lebanese Civil War was a multifaceted civil war in Lebanon, lasting from 1975 to 1990 and resulting in an estimated 120,000 fatalities
years.name: Lebanese Civil War

years.info: The Cambodian–Vietnamese War, known in Vietnam as the Counter-offensive on the Southwestern border, and by Cambodian nationalists as the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia
years.name: Cambodian–Vietnamese War

years.info: The insurgency in Laos refers to the ongoing, albeit sporadic, military conflict between the Lao People's Army, and Vietnam People's Army opposed primarily by members of the former Secret Army
years.name: Insurgency in Laos

years.info: The Indonesian invasion of East Timor, known in Indonesia as Operation Lotus, began on 7 December 1975 when the Indonesian military invaded East Timor under the pretext of anti-colonialism and anti-communism to overthrow the Fretilin regime that had emerged in 1974
years.name: Indonesian invasion of East Timor

years.info: The Lost Rebellion is an acclaimed classic on the rise of Kashmir militancy, which chronicles how a simple call for azadi by bands of disgruntled youth was transformed within a year into a full-scale jihad against India
years.name: Rebellion of the Lost [pt]

years.info: The Dirty War is the name used by the military junta or civic-military dictatorship of Argentina for the period of state terrorism in Argentina from 1976 to 1983 as a part of Operation Condor
years.name: Dirty War

years.info: The insurgency in Aceh, officially designated the Aceh disturbance by the Indonesian government, was a conflict fought by the Free Aceh Movement between 1976 and 2005, with the goal of making the province of Aceh independent from Indonesia
years.name: Insurgency in Aceh

years.info: Political violence in Turkey became a serious problem in the late 1970s and was even described as a low-level war. The death squads of Turkish right-wing ultranationalist groups, sometimes allied with the state, against the resistance of the left-wing opposition inflicted some 5,000 casualties
years.name: Political violence in Turkey (1976–80)

years.info: Ba'ath Party restricted holding religious rituals and also setting up any mawkib[1], and banned any procession. But, people of Najaf prepared for organizing Arba'in procession on Safar 15, 1397/February 5, 1977. A caravan of thirty thousand people moved toward Karbala. The government encountered this movement since the beginning and some people were martyred
years.name: Safar uprising

years.info: The Mozambican Civil War was a civil war fought in Mozambique from 1977 to 1992. Like many regional African conflicts during the late twentieth century, the Mozambican Civil War possessed local dynamics but was also exacerbated greatly by the polarizing effects of Cold War politics.
years.name: Mozambican Civil War

years.info: The Egyptian–Libyan War or the Four Day War was a short border war fought between Libya and Egypt that lasted from 21 to 24 July 1977
years.name: Libyan–Egyptian War

years.info: The Ogaden War, or the Ethio-Somali War, was a Somali military offensive between July 1977 and March 1978 over the Ethiopian sector of Ogaden, which began with the Somali invasion of Ethiopia. The Soviet Union disapproved of the invasion and ceased its support of Somalia, instead starting to support Ethiopia
years.name: Ethio-Somali War

years.info: The Chittagong Hill Tracts conflict was a political and armed conflict between the government of Bangladesh and the Parbatya Chattagram Jana Samhati Samiti and its armed wing
years.name: Chittagong Hill Tracts conflict

years.info: Shaba I was a conflict in Zaire's Shaba Province lasting from March 8 to May 26, 1977. The conflict began when the Front for the National Liberation of the Congo, a group of about 2,000 Katangan Congolese
years.name: Shaba I

years.info: Shaba II was a brief conflict fought in the Zairean province of Shaba in 1978. The conflict broke out on 11 May 1978 after 6,500 rebels from the Congolese National Liberation Front
years.name: Shaba II

years.info: The 1978 South Lebanon conflict was an invasion of Lebanon up to the Litani River, carried out by the Israel Defense Forces in 1978 in response to the Coastal Road massacre
years.name: 1978 South Lebanon conflict

years.info: The Uganda–Tanzania War, known in Tanzania as the Kagera War and in Uganda as the 1979 Liberation War, was fought between Uganda and Tanzania from October 1978 until June 1979 and led to the overthrow of Ugandan President Idi Amin.
years.name: Uganda–Tanzania War

years.info: The Chadian–Libyan conflict was a series of military campaigns in Chad between 1978 and 1987, fought between Libyan and allied Chadian forces against Chadian groups supported by France, with the occasional involvement of other foreign countries and factions
years.name: Chadian–Libyan conflict

years.info: The Kurdish–Turkish conflict is an armed conflict between the Republic of Turkey and various Kurdish insurgent groups who have demanded separation from Turkey to create an independent Kurdistan, or to secure autonomy and greater political and cultural rights for Kurds inside the Republic of Turkey.
years.name: Kurdish–Turkish conflict

years.info: The NDF Rebellion was an uprising in the Yemen Arab Republic by the National Democratic Front, under Yahya Shami, between 1978 and 1982.
years.name: NDF Rebellion

years.info: The Grand Mosque seizure occurred during November and December 1979 when extremist insurgents calling for the overthrow of the House of Saud took over Masjid al-Haram in Mecca, Saudi Arabia.
years.name: Grand Mosque seizure

years.info: The 1979 Herat uprising was an insurrection that took place in and around the city of Herat, Afghanistan in March 1979. It included both a popular uprising and a mutiny of Afghan Army troops against the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
years.name: 1979 Herat uprising

years.info: The Second Yemenite War was a short military conflict between the Yemen Arab Republic and the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen
years.name: Yemenite War of 1979

years.info: The Iranian Revolution; locally known as the Islamic Revolution was a series of events that culminated in the overthrow of the Pahlavi dynasty under Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi
years.name: Iranian Revolution

years.info: The 1979 Khuzestan uprising was one of the nationwide uprisings in Iran, which erupted in the aftermath of the Iranian Revolution. The unrest was fed by Arab demands for autonomy. The uprising was effectively quelled by Iranian security forces, resulting in more than a hundred people on both sides killed.
years.name: 1979 Khuzestan uprising

years.info: The Sino-Vietnamese War was a border war fought between the People's Republic of China and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam in early 1979. China launched an offensive in response to Vietnam's actions against the Khmer Rouge in 1978, which ended the rule of the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge
years.name: Sino-Vietnamese War

years.info: The Sino-Vietnamese conflicts of 1979–1991 were a series of border and naval clashes between the People's Republic of China and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam following the Sino-Vietnamese War in 1979. These clashes lasted from the end of the Sino-Vietnamese War until the normalization of ties in 1991.
years.name: Sino-Vietnamese conflicts 1979–90

years.info: The Islamist uprising in Syria comprised a series of revolts and armed insurgencies by Sunni Islamists, mainly members of the Muslim Brotherhood from 1976 until 1982.
years.name: Islamist uprising in Syria

years.info: The 1979 Kurdish rebellion in Iran erupted in mid-March 1979, some two months after the completion of the Iranian Revolution. It subsequently became the largest among the nationwide uprisings in Iran against the new state and one of the most intense Kurdish rebellions in modern Iran
years.name: 1979 Kurdish rebellion in Iran

years.info: The group was founded in September 2003, as an umbrella organization for guerrillas, with former members of Ansar al-Islam who had fled to Iran after a 2003 joint operation by Iraqi and US forces.Their goal was to expel U.S. occupation forces from Iraq.
years.name: Al-Ansar insurgency

years.info: The 1979–1980 Shia uprising in Iraq, also known as the First Sadr Uprising, took place as a followup to the Iranian Revolution (1978–1979) in neighbouring Iran, as the Shia Iraqi clerics vowed to overthrow Ba'athist Iraq, dominated by (secular) Sunni Muslims - specifically the Saddam Hussein family.
years.name: 1979–1980 Shia uprising in Iraq

years.info: The Soviet–Afghan War was a conflict wherein insurgent groups, as well as smaller Maoist groups, fought a nine-year guerrilla war against the Soviet Army and the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan government throughout the 1980s, mostly in the Afghan countryside
years.name: Soviet–Afghan War

years.info: The Salvadoran Civil War was a civil war in El Salvador which was fought between the military-led junta government of El Salvador and the Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front from 15 October 1979 to 16 January 1992
years.name: Salvadoran Civil War
